As the leader, Sary will spend her loan portion to buy fertilizer and rice seed for replanting the rainy season rice. She hopes to gain a good yield from her crop so she can double her income and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and rice seed for replanting the rainy season rice.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Cheung Prey district

loans.name: Sinoun's Group

texts.en:
Originally from a rural village of the Sampov Means district of Pursat province, Sinoun is a 55-year-old married mother of five children. Rice farming has been the main source of her family’s income for over 10 years, and to better support the family and help to earn more income she also sells grocery items in the village. She can earn about 35,000 KHR per day to meet her family’s needs and manages to save about 20,000 KHR each day for their future needs. 

Sinoun has been with VisionFund for three cycles and completely paid back the past loans. The past loans have helped Sinoun better support her family members. Now she is leading her group to apply for a loan. Sinoun, who is the leader, wants to use her portion to buy fertilizers for her farmland and use a portion of it to buy more grocery items to resell. With this loan, she hopes to grow her rice fruitfully and healthily and also hopes to make more income to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for her farmland

loans.name: Kanykey

texts.ru: Каныкей 46 лет, замужем, вместе с супругом воспитывают 3 детей. У Каныкей - среднее образование, в качестве основного дохода для своей семьи Каныкей занимается животноводством и полеводством, стартовав 13 лет назад, с покупки скота на 10,000 сом KGS. Благодаря упорному труду Каныкей, в ее хозяйстве на сегодняшний день имеется: 2 дойные коровы и 10 овец, а также имеет земельный надел размером 0,85 ГА, на которой ежегодно сажает подсолнух и кукурузу. Ежемесячный доход составляет 10,000 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Каныкей обратилась в Микрофинансовый банк «Бай –Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 110,000 сом (KGS) на покупку овец для дальнейшего откорма и перепродажи. Доходы от кредита Каныкей планирует вложить в дальнейшее приумножение количества домашней скотины, и планирует накопить средства на покупку участка для постройки дома.
texts.en:
Kanykey is 46 years old, married and raising three children together with her husband. Kanykey has secondary education. As the main income for her family, Kanykey works with livestock breeding and field crop cultivation, after having started 13 years ago with the purchase of livestock for 10,000 som (KGS). Thanks to Kanykey's persistent work, her farm currently has two dairy cows and 10 sheep. She also has a plot of land of 0.85 hectares on which she plants sunflower and sweet corn. The monthly income is 10,000 som (KGS).

With an aim to further develop her business, Kanykey turned to the microfinance bank "Bai Tushum & Partners" for a loan in the amount of 110,000 som (KGS) for the purchase of sheep to fatten and resell. Kanykey plans to invest the income from the loan in further increasing the number of household animals, and plans to save money for purchasing land for building a house on.

loans.use: to purchase sheep for fattening and reselling

loans.name: Om Wael Group

texts.en: This group is called Om Wael. The group consists of four ladies who live together in Sana'a, Yemen. All of them are working on embroidering ladies' fabrics. The group took a loan of 140,000 YER. Seham is 24 years old. She is a married woman and has two children. She has been working in embroidery for eight years. She started her business as a hobby at her home where she embroidered at her leisure. She strives as much as possible to expand her business so that she can improve the living conditions of her family. She applied for a loan of 40,000 YER from AMB to buy embroidery materials such as needles, thread, and fabrics for her business. In the future, she would like to expand her business and complete building her house.

loans.use: to buy embroidery materials such as needles, thread, and fabrics for her business.

loans.name: Abdusaid

texts.ru: Абдусаид родился в 1995 года. Он трудолюбивый и умный молодой человек. Он не женат и живет с родителями. Абдусаид с детства всегда мечтал получить высшее образование. Он учился в средней школе на отлично и хорошо. Он активно участвовал во всех общественных мероприятиях. Абдусаид в этом году окончил среднюю школу и поступил в университет. Он студент 1 курса и теперь он должен оплатить за учебный договор. Он запрашивает займ для оплаты учебного договора. Он ждет вашу доброту и надеется на ваше милосердие.
texts.en:
Abdusaid was born in 1995. He is a hardworking and smart young man. He is not married and lives with his parents. Abdusaid has dreamed of getting higher education since childhood. He studied well at high school, and actively participated in all community events. 

Abdusaid finished high school and started university this year. He is a first year student and currently he needs to pay for his tuition. He requests a loan to pay for tuition. He awaits your kindness and hopes for your charity.

loans.use: To pay for his education

loans.name: Breezy

texts.en:
This is Breezy, 33, a resident of Malibay, Pasay, Philippines. She is single, and she is helping her parents manage their household. She works hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Breezy operates a variety store.  In the Philippines, a variety store is a retail store that sells inexpensive items, often with a single price for every item in the store.  It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She makes money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. She also sells shoes and belts for additional income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

She is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan to help her continue in the operation of her business. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory.

Breezy dreams of having another business and hopes to have good health.  She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of their lives and business every week.  There she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet every week.  A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay their Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries, and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Miller

texts.es: Miller, de 40 años, está casado y tiene 3 hijos con quienes vive en su casa propia. Miller se dedica a la siembra de cacao, Yucas y otros productos de su chacra, durante mucho tiempo sufrió algunos contratiempos en su vida, esto debido a que no tenía un ingreso propio de dinero para su hogar, es por eso que desde hace 10 años decidió empezar un nuevo proyecto con ganas de sobresalir. Pensó que sus amigos, vecinos o familiares desearían comprar productos de su terreno agrícola dependiendo de la temporada en la que se encuentren, es así que inicio su negocio que ahora le da muy buenos resultados. Le gusta lo que hace, pues le permite tener tiempo para poder estar al cuidado de sus animales y su vivienda, además que desde que empezó con su negocio le está yendo bien en su economía, ya que tienen ingresos para su hogar, desea seguir creciendo, por eso tiene en mente ampliar sus ventas. Por Tanto éste es su primer crédito con Kiva, por ello espera de su colaboración para continuar con sus objetivos, por otro lado se compromete a pagar sus cuotas de manera puntual. Con el monto solicitado de 1000 soles comprará abono orgánico para sus sembríos.
texts.en: Miller, who is 40-years old, is married and has three children who live with him in the house that he owns.  Miller makes his living planting cacao, yucca and other products on his small farm.  For a long time, Miller suffered setbacks in his life as he did not have his own income to support his household.  And so, ten years ago he decided to start a new project with the goal of making a name for himself.  He thought that his fiends, neighbors and family would want to purchase products from his land, in accordance with the season.  He started his business and it is now doing very well.  Miller likes what he does, as it allows him to have time to take care of his animals and his household.  In addition, since he started his business, his finances are doing very well.  He now has money for his household, and he hopes to continue growing, which is why he is thinking of expanding his sales.  This is his first loan with Kiva.  He hopes to collaborate with Kiva to be able to continue with his objectives.  At the same time, he promises to punctually repay his loan.  With the requested sum of 1000 soles (USD $375), he will purchase organic compost for his sown fields.

loans.use: to purchase organic compost for his plants.

loans.name: Sinoun's Group

texts.en:
Sinoun is 35 years old and married. She lives with her family in a rural area located in the Sangke district of Battambang province. She has four dependent children to take care of, three of whom are in school while another one is too young for school. Rice farming is the only primary source of her family’s income to make a living and she has been in this business for 10 years. With the current business, she can earn approximately 27,000 KHR per day and save about 10,000 KHR each day for the future needs.

This is the first microloan for Sinoun with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund. Now leading her group to apply for a loan, Sinoun will use her portion to buy rice seeds and fertilizers for her farmland. She hopes to increase her current business so as to earn a larger income to make a better living and keep her children in school.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds and fertilizers for her farmland

loans.name: Tun's Group

texts.en:
Tun, 56, lives with her husband and four children in a rural village of the Moung Russey district, Cambodia. To feed the family, Tun and her husband earn a living as farmers. They have been farming rice for over 40 years, earning about 26,000 KHR per day to spend on their family’s needs. 

Tun has been with VisionFund for three cycles and completely paid back the past loans. Now she is leading her group to ask for a loan of 1,000,000 KHR each. As the leader, Tun is going to use her portion to buy fertilizers for her farmland. She hopes to increase her crop yields so as to generate more income to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for her farmland

loans.name: Clemencia

texts.es:
Clemencia de 41 años de edad, se le conoce como una persona responsable y muy trabajadora, ella vive con su compañero de vida y sus 5 hijas, las cuales 3 trabajan y 2 estudian, y con ella viven 4 nietos los cuales son 2 hombrecitos y 2 mujercitas, dos de ellos estudian la escuela básica y los demás los cuida en sus ratos libres.

Posee 15 años de experiencia en la actividad comercial, que realiza la cual es venta de tamales, elotes, riguas, tortillas, etc. Por lo cual, ella mantiene una gran diversidad de clientes y le permite seguir creciendo en su negocio.

El crédito lo solicita  para la compra de productos para la elaboración de sus productos típicos y la otra parte del crédito es para cancelar los papeles de la escrituración del terreno que le donaron, y así asegurar el terreno el cual quedara a su nombre y el de sus hijos.

El beneficio del crédito, es que además de ayudarle a producir más en el negocio, que es fundamental en los ingresos de su hogar, se generara la satisfacción de tener a su nombre la propiedad en la cual ella vive.
texts.en:
Clemencia, 41, is known as a responsible and hard working person. She lives with her long term partner and their 5 children, three of which work and the other 2 are studying. Four grandchildren also living with them - two little boys and two little girls, two of which are in school and she looks after the others in her free time. 

She has 15 years of experience in commerce, selling tamales, corn on the cob, riguas, tortillas, etc. She has a wide range of customers, which allows her to continue growing her business.

She is requesting part of the loan to buy ingredients for making her typical products and the other art is to pay off the loan papers on the land so that she can ensure that the land will stay in her name and her children's.

The loan will also benefit her as she will be able to produce more in her business, which is fundamental for her household income. It will give her the satisfaction of owning the property where she lives.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for making typical products with part and the other part is to pay off the loan on the land she has been given.

loans.name: Lito

texts.en:
Lito is a resident from the town of San Miguel, Bohol. He is a married man and a father of eight children. Lito is a scrap buyer, which involves the buying and reselling of scrap metals, aluminum, and copper wires and any other recyclable materials from his neighborhood.

Lito is asking for a loan to buy more scrap to sell. With this, he will be able to improve his business, thus augmenting his profit and income.

loans.use: to buy more scrap to sell

loans.name: Emelita

texts.en: Emelita is 36 and married to a lumberyard operator. She runs a general store to make a living.  In 2008, she joined Gata Daku MPC and she gained access to microfinance services and was able to borrow a loan of 7,000 PHP to buy stock like dried fish and canned goods to sell. She hopes to see her children successful and to be able to have a better living in the near future.

loans.use: to buy stock like dried fish and canned goods to sell

location.town: San Carlos, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Emelyn

texts.en:
This is Emelyn, 34, resident of Malibay, Pasay, Philippines. She is married to Sandy, a butcher, and they have children. She and her husband manage their household while operating her business. She is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Emelyn operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is a retail store that sells inexpensive items, often with a single price for all items in the store. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil or an egg. Emelyn earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

She is requesting a PHP 45,000 loan to help her continue in the operation of her business. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory.

Emelyn hopes to expand her business and dreams to give her children a good life and education.  Every week, she meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

*All Center for Community Transformation (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries, and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Seth

texts.en:
Seth is a married man who is very hard-working and responsible.  He lives at his own house, which has neither electricity nor piped water.

For the past year, he has operated a "bodaboda" (motorcycle) transport business. His potential customers are town dwellers.  He cites the high cost of maintanince as being his major challenge.

With the KSH 30,000, he wants to purchase spare parts and paint his motorcycle.  He joined Yehu to gain access to loans to improve his living standards.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts and paint his motorcycle

loans.name: Jamida

texts.en:
Jamida is a hard-working woman with four children who lives in Fort Portal, Uganda.

Jamida operates a bar business, but she also sells firewood in order to raise money to support her family.  Customers not paying on time and the high cost of rent pose a challenge to her business growth.  

Jamida intends to use the loan to buy alcohol beverages and fish to sell.  Her dream is to own a modern bar that sells alcoholic drinks and food.

loans.use: to buy alcoholic beverages and fish to sell at her bar

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia is 41 years old, and she is happy being a member of PMPC. She is a farmer and earns a meager income doing this type of work. 

Through Paglaum MPC, she obtained the capital to start up her farming activities. Now she is requesting a loan of PHP 7,000 to buy additional feed. 

She really hopes and prays that her business will grow and benefit her family, in addition to the income of her husband. Someday, she wants to buy additional land to culivate other crops.

loans.use: to buy additional feed for her farm

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
Estrella is 55 years old from Ozamiz City.  She has enjoyed being a member of PMPC for seven years now. She is married and blessed with one child. 

She earns a living through her store. She has applied for a loan from PMPC to buy more inventory to sell, like sacks of rice and cases of softdrinks.

Estrella wishes to have her house repaired and wants to save more with PMPC.

loans.use: to buy more inventory to sell, like sacks of rice and cases of softdrinks

loans.name: Annie

texts.en: Annie is a member of PMPC who lives in Ozamiz City. She is 44 years old, married and the mother of six children. She runs a store that genertaes a meager income of Php 3,600 per month. She has applied for a loan to buy additional items for her store, including soft drinks, canned goods, noodles and other food items. Annie dreams of improving her family's living conditions and wants to save for the future.

loans.use: to buy additional items for her store, including soft drinks, canned goods and noodles.

location.town: Ozamis-Sangay Daku, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidenta

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en: Maribel resides in the village of Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur with her children. Her live-in partner works as a seaman while she runs a retail business selling ready-to-wear articles, beauty products and kitchenware. She joined Gata Daku MPC this year and requested a loan of 7,000.00 PHP to purchase additional plastic ware for sale. She hopes to gain more income to use in expanding her business.  She also wants to improve the general living condition of her family in the future.

loans.use: to purchase additional plastic ware for sale

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida is 42 years old and very responsible with her household obligations. She has always been known to provide the best for her family. She currently lives with her husband and five children in Ozamiz City. She and her husband are farmers who plant corn, vegetables and beans.

Nida wants to increase sales. Consequently, she has requested a loan that will enable her to purchase seed, compost and fertilizer, among other items, so that she and her husband can continue to put bread on the table of their home.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Abbas

texts.en: Abbas is 38 years old, married, and has a son. He is an internally displaced person (IDP) from the city of Fuzuli in Azerbaijan who now lives in the Fuzuli region. His wife stays at home, so he is the only one earning an income, while his son goes to school. Abbas started his taxi business five years ago. Now he needs a loan of 900 Azerbaijani manats (AZN) to repair the engine of his car. In the future, he wants to buy a new car as this will be more profitable for his business. Abbas is thankful to Komak and Kiva for supporting him.

loans.use: to repair the engine of a car used for his taxi business

loans.name: Emelito

texts.en:
Emelito is married, with with two children. He resides in Militar, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. 

His wife serves as a barangay councilor while he operates a transportation service, to make a living. He has been doing this for three years to support the needs of his family. Emelito successfully repaid his previous loan from Gata Daku Multi-Purpose Cooperative (GDMPC) which he used to purchase tires.  

He is borrowing a new loan of PHP 5,000 from GDMPC to be used for repairs and maintenance of his existing motorcycle. He wants to improve the general living situation of his family and be able to send his children to school.

loans.use: to pay for repairs and maintenance of his existing motorcycle.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is a 64-year-old businesswoman from Ozamiz City. She is married and has eight children. She has applied for membership with PMPC for her business. She runs a store that earns enough to provide for her family.

She has applied for a loan to buy more stock for her sari-sari (convenience) store such as canned goods, noodles and detergents. She wants to save more for the improvement of her house.

loans.use: to buy more stock for her sari-sari store business like canned goods, noodles and detergents

loans.name: Esteban

texts.es: Esteban, de 48 años, está casado con Susana y tiene 3 hijos de 24, 23 y 08 años de edad con quienes vive en su casa propia. Esteban, es una mujer que no le teme a los grandes retos, es así que al ver la gran necesidad de dinero que padecía cada mes, decidió intentar incrementar sus ingresos de una manera que no le interfiera con su trabajo en la una empresa privada de la ciudad en donde trabaja como operario de limpieza, entonces decidió un día comenzar a sembrar productos alternativos en sus terrenos de cultivos los cuales constan de cacao, café, plátano, etc. Hace ya más de 04 años comenzó a hacer éste trabajo el cual lo hace con la ayuda de sus hijos mayores.Le está yendo muy buen ya que tiene buenos pedidos y nunca falla a nadie en el mercado, se siente tranquilo ya que a fin de mes ve buenos ingresos a su hogar y así puede darles una mejor calidad de vida a su familia.  Espera que le siga yendo bien, ya que diariamente se incrementan más los pedidos y tiene que empezar a expandir su negocio. Este es su primer crédito con Kiva, está muy contenta de saber que tiene un apoyo financiero, ya que así se siente segura de avanzar con su trabajo.  Por otro lado, se compromete a ser puntual con el pago de sus cuotas. Con el monto solicitado de 2000 soles, comprará abono orgánico y  plantas para sus terrenos de cultivo.
texts.en:
Esteban, 48, is married to Susana and has 3 children aged 24, 23 and 8 who live with him in his own home.

Esteban is a man who is not afraid of the big challenges, this is how he sees the great necessity of the money that they pay every month. He decided to increase his income in a way that would not interfere with his job at a private business in the city where he works as a cleaner. 

One day he decided to grow alternative products on his land, including cocoa, coffee, banana, etc. He started this business 4 years ago with the help of his eldest sons. It is going well as he already has good orders and he never fails anyone in the market, he feels content as at the end of the month he sees good income in his home and he can give a better quality of life to his family.

He hopes that it will continue going well, as his orders are already increasing daily and he has to start expanding his business. This is his first loan with Kiva, he is very happy to know that he has financial support, as it makes him feel safe to take his business forward. On the other hand, he promises to be punctual with his payments. With the amount of 2000 PEN he will buy organic manure and plants for his land.

loans.use: to buy organic manure and plants

loans.name: Delailah

texts.en: Delilah is a retired teacher and a wife of a farmer residing in a village of Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. To make a living, she helps her husband operate and manage their own farm. She joined GDMPC and Delilah successfully repaid her previous loan that she used to improve their farm. She requested a new loan of 50,000.00 PHP to cover the costs of farm fertilization, plowing and planting rice. She wants to use the generated income for future emergencies and savings.

loans.use: to cover the costs of farm fertilization, plowing and planting rice

loans.name: Paulita

texts.en:
Paulita is from Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur, in the Philippines. She is separated, a 61-year-old lady with six children. 

To make a living, Paulita operates a general store. She has been engaged in this business for four years, and she earns PHP 12,000 per month from these activities. 

In 2010, Paulita joined GDMPC, and she has successfully repaid her previous loan, which she used to add inventory to her business. 

Recently, Paulita has requested a loan of PHP 60,000, which she will use to buy additional beauty products for sale.

She plans to use the additional revenue that the loan generates to add to her reserve for future emergencies and to further improve her family's general living conditions.

loans.use: to buy additional beauty products for sale

loans.name: Hermosa

texts.en:
Hermosa is very thankful for the financial assistance given to her. She previously accessed an 30,000 PHP loan that she utilized to buy gardening materials and supplies needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household, and business expenditures. She also sells meat for additional income.

She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy gardening materials like wire and baskets and supplies such as seeds and fertilizer needed in her business. Her profits from her business will definitely help her sustain their daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Hermosa hopes to be more successful in her business and dreams to become rich. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for gardening materials like wire and baskets and supplies such as seeds and fertilizer needed in her business.

loans.name: Eulalia

texts.en: Eulalia is married with five children residing in a village of Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. To make a living, she makes ice cream and her husband sells it in town. For five years they have been selling ice cream because it helps a lot to support their needs. She joined Gata Daku MPC and borrowed a loan of 7,000 PHP to purchase more raw ingredients for ice cream. She is thankful to GDMPC, which gives them a chance to have the capital to continue their small business. She wants to improve the general living condition of the family in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase more raw ingredients for ice cream

loans.name: Kicuucu Tweyimukye Group

texts.en: Joseph is a 21-year-old married man living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is a member of the above mentioned group in which each member guarantees the others in accessing a loan that is why the eighth person appears in the photo even when he is not taking a loan. He operates a retail shop alongside farming, and, with the proceeds, he has been able to pay school fees for his children. Price fluctuations and the high cost of rent are his major challenges, while his dream is to own a wholesale shop. Joseph intends to use the loan to buy salt, soap, rice, and flour to sell.

loans.use: to buy salt, soap, rice, and flour to sell.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is 38 years old, a single mother of two children, and stays with her mum. She runs a grocery business and also supplies charcoal. She has been in this business for 10 years now. 

She plans to use the loan to purchase more grocery items to sell. These include vegetables, fruits, potatoes, tomatoes, and onions. She also plans to buy more stock of charcoal for supply. This is her first loan term with KADET LTD and she plans to save her anticipated profits which will finance her future projects. 

Her future hopes and dreams are to expand her grocery business, own her own car for supplying goods to various markets in other towns, and to have a financially stable family.

loans.use: To buy more stock of grocery items to sell.

loans.name: Rubaga Abesiga Mukan Group

texts.en:
Mary is a widow with four children. She lost her husband in 1990, leaving her with the four children and no clear source of income to maintain her family. Thus Mary started her roadside trading stall in 1991. She deals in vegetables and other fast-moving perishable goods like fish and tomatoes, selling them to passersby. 

Her major problem is limited income to expand her business. However, Mary is hardworking and determined that with enough income (and the boost from the loan), she could do much more than she is doing. In the photo (far left is the group chairperson who has a running loan but is not borrowing with this particular subgroup).

loans.use: To buy groceries to sell

loans.name: Eang's Group

texts.en:
Eang, 53, is married with five children. Her family lives in a house with a thatched roof located in Banteay Meanchey province’s Moungkul Borey district. The main sources of her family’s income are from farming rice and raising pigs in her village. She has been running her business for 23 years, earning about KHR 26,000 per day, and she is able to save about KHR 10,000 each day. 

Eang received her first loan with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund, six cycles ago and has effectively used it to sustain her family’s business and support her family’s needs. With a good business, she is leading her group to apply for a loan. As the leader, she is going to use her portion to buy more piglets for raising and also use a portion of it to spend on buying more household supplies. She hopes to increase her family’s income to make a better living.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for raising

location.town: Banteay Meanchey Province, Mongkul Borey District

loans.name: Carolina

texts.en:
This is Carolina. She previously accessed a 10,000 PHP loan that she used to buy spare parts, accessories, and for the maintenance of their tricycle unit. Her earnings were a big help in their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 10,000 PHP loan to buy spare parts and pay for the maintenance of their tricycle unit. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain their daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Carolina dreams of having additional units of tricycles, and hopes that her child will finish his studies. She meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week, and she draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for spare parts and accessories for her tricycle, and for maintenance.

loans.name: Noem's Group

texts.en:
Noem is 35 and married. She has two children, both of whom are dependents and still in school. Living in a village of the Tbaung Khmum district, Noem has been farming rice and working for others for a fee. Having been in this business for ten years, she manages to earn about 26,000 KHR per day to feed her family.

This is the first loan for Noem with VisionFund. She is leading her group to request a loan of 1,000,000 KHR each. Noem, who is the leader, will use her portion to buy fertilizer for her farmland, and will use a portion of it to spend for labor. 

She hopes to earn more income from her current business.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her farmland

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Tbaung Khmum district

loans.name: Khusrav

texts.ru: Хусрав родился в 1994 года. Он живет с родителями. Он в этом году успешно окончил среднюю школу и поступил в Таджикский Государственный Национальный Университет. Хусрав начитанный молодой человек. Он регулярно посещает библиотеку. Хусрав имеет много друзей, и все его друзья дорожат его дружбой. Хусрав не в состоянии оплатить за учебный договор, так как его родители получают маленькую зарплату. Он запрашивает займ для оплаты учебного договора. Он ждет вашу доброту.
texts.en: Khusrav was born in 1994.  He lives with his parents.  He successfully completed a secondary school this year and was accepted to the Tajikistan State National University.  Khusrav is a well-read young person.  He regularly visits a library.  Khusrav has many friends, and all of them value his friendship.  Khusrav cannot pay for his tuition because his parents earn a small salary.  He is requesting this loan to pay for his tuition contract.  He awaits your kindness.

loans.use: to pay for education

loans.name: Nuimi

texts.es: Nuimi, de 40 años, está casada con Pedro y tiene 2 hijos con quienes vive en su casa propia. Nuimi se dedica a la agricultura por está razón vende sus productos como piña, cacao, plátano, entre otros, en el mercado de su localidad en donde oferta todos sus productos, atendiendo muy amablemente a sus clientes quienes son en su mayoría sus propios vecinos, y la recomiendan a otros personas que con el tiempo se vuelven sus clientes habituales. Se inició hace más de 08 años con un préstamo particular, comprando y vendiendo en pocas cantidades, para luego ir aumentando de acuerdo a la demanda, hasta el momento lo realiza sola, pero en ocasiones contrata obreros para la siembra y cosecha. Además comenta que le gusta su negocio pues conoce de agricultura y se decidió a empezar por la necesidad de contar con un ingreso propio y tener un oficio pues la pensión para sus hijos no les alcanzaba y tenía apuros económicos. Ahora viendo los buenos resultados desea ampliar su siembra. Este es su primer crédito con Kiva y se siente agradecida por el apoyo financiero que recibe para seguir adelante, además se compromete a pagar sus cuotas de manera puntual. Con el monto solicitado de 1500 nuevo soles comprará abono orgánico y semillas para continuar con sus sembríos.
texts.en: Nuimi, is 40, she is married to Pedro and has two children that live in a house they own.  Nuimi works in agriculture, she sells her products such as pineapple, cacao, bananas, and others at the local market, this is where she offers them, services her customers nicely who in their majority are neighbors that recommend her to other people who with time become regular customers.  She started more than eight years ago with a private loan, buying and selling in small quantities, to then increase according to demand, up to this point she has done this on her own, but occasionally she hires workers for seeding and harvesting.  She comments that she likes this business because she knows about agriculture and decided to start due to the need to have her own income and have a trade, because the money for their children wasn't enough and they had economic difficulties.  Now seeing the good results she wants to expand her seeding area.  This is her first loan with Kiva and she is thankful for the financial support that she gets to continue moving forward, she commits to pay for the loan punctually.  With the amount requested of 1,500 PEN she will buy organic fertilizer and seed to continue working in her land.

loans.use: to buy organic fertilizer and seed.

loans.name: Alberto

texts.es: Alberto tiene 46 años de edad, está casado y tiene 2 hijos con quienes vive en su casa propia. Su actividad económica se centra en la agricultura, desde muy joven fue inculcado en está actividad por está razón tiene un promedio de 10 años de experiencia, lo primero que hizo fue comprar sus terrenos de cultivo. En sus inicios tuvo muchas dificultades ya que no contaban con  dinero suficiente para adquirir los terrenos pero gracias al apoyo de su familia logro comprarlos y comenzar a realizar los sembríos. Con la ganancia de la cosecha de sus cultivos mantiene a su familia. Este es su primer préstamo con Kiva y se siente agradecido por el apoyo financiero que recibe para seguir adelante, además se compromete a pagar sus cuotas de manera puntual. El dinero solicitado de S/.1500.00, lo invertirá en el mantenimiento de sus cultivos de cacao.
texts.en:
Alberto is a 46-year old man who is married and has two children living at home. He works in agriculture and has been learning the profession since he was very young, which is why he has an average of 10 years of experience. The beginnings were not easy as he did not have enough money to buy the land plots, but thanks to the support of his family he was able to buy them and start sowing. He supports his family with the income generated by the harvest. 

This is his first loan with Kiva and he is grateful for the financial support he receives to get ahead. He commits to repay as scheduled. The requested 1,500 soles will be invested in maintaining his cocoa plantations.

loans.use: to maintain his plantations.

loans.name: Jamine's Group

texts.en:
Jamine is 60 years old and has 2 children. Jamine lives in Jepkoyai village in Kapchegung in Kenya. Jepkoyai does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Jamine and her family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Jamine owns a business, but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Jamine and other promoters in her community need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Jamine will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser, and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. She volunteered to be a promoter because she loves engaging with her community. She believes that the dispenser will protect the community's health. 

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits.  Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Jamine's community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To install and maintain chlorine dispensers to provide access to safe drinking water for the community.

loans.name: Niva's Group

texts.en:
In Ganyamosi village in Kenya, Niva has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. Niva is a friendly, hardworking, reliable and trustworthy member of the community with 5 children who are 17, 15, 12, 8 and 7 years old respectively. She lives in a house with concrete walls and an iron roof with her family. 
Ganyamosi village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from an unprotected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases.  Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Niva and the 15 other households using the local water source need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 
Niva has volunteered to act as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. She volunteered to be the promoter because she believes chlorine will kill the bacteria in the drinking water thus preventing sickness that would cause the children to miss school.
The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Niva’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To ensure that the community has access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers.

loans.name: Festo's Group

texts.en:
Festo is 23 years old and lives in Eramba village in Tigoi, Kenya.  Eramba village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Festo and his family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.
Festo grows grains and vegetables, but has also volunteered his time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser that enables his community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Festo and other promoters in his community need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Festo will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser, and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Festo is proud to have been elected as the promoter by his community. He is pleased that the dispenser will make water safe for drinking.
The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits.  Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Festo’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To allow the community to treat their water to make it safe to drink using chlorine dispensers.

loans.name: Linet's Group

texts.en:
In Kimogoi village in Gamoi, Kenya, Linet has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. Linet is a friendly, well-liked, hardworking and reliable member of the community with 4 boys who are aged 14, 13, 8, and 6. she lives in a semi-permanent house (made of mud walls, dirt floor and an iron roof) with her family. 
Kimogoi village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from the a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Linet and the 21 other households using the local water source need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers in the area. 
Linet has volunteered to act as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. She volunteered to be the promoter because she believes chlorine will fight diseases that would have otherwise affected the productivity of members of her family and community. 
The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits.  Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Linet’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To provide communities with free access to chlorine to treat their drinking water.

loans.name: Gladys' Group

texts.en:
Gladys is a 53-year-old single mother. She lives in Buvai village in Gamoi, Kenya with her 4 children, her sister, 2 nieces and 2 nephews. Buvai does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from an unprotected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Gladys and her family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.
Gladys works as a subsistence farmer, but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Gladys and the other dispenser promoters in her community need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Gladys will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser, and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Gladys wants to be a promoter because she wants to help her community to be able to drink treated water. She believes that the dispenser will protect the community from diarrheal diseases.
The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (evidenceaction.org) on behalf of Glady's community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Gladys’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To support an innovative water treatment technology - chlorine dispensers.

loans.name: Gulgaky

texts.ru: Гулгакы 39 лет, замужем, вместе с супругом воспитывают 3 детей. У Гулгакы- среднее образование, в качестве основного дохода для своей семьи Гулгакы занимается животноводством, стартовав 14 лет назад, с покупки скота на 2,000 сом KGS. Благодаря упорному труду Гулгакы, в ее хозяйстве на сегодняшний день имеется: 1 дойная корова, 1 нетель, 1 теленок, также обрабатывает земельную долю размером 0,60 ГА, на которой ежегодно выращивает клевер. Ежемесячный доход составляет 15,000 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Гулгакы обратилась в Микрофинансовый банк «Бай –Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 70,000 сом (KGS) на покупку коров для увеличения поголовья скота. Доходы от кредита Гулгакы планирует вложить в дальнейшее приумножение количества домашней скотины, и планирует накопить средства на дальнейшее обучение детей.
texts.en: Gulgaky is 39 years old, married and raising three children together with her husband.  Gulgaky has a secondary education.  To provide the primary source of income for her family, she is involved in animal husbandry, having started 14 years ago with a purchase of livestock with 2,000 som (KGS). Thanks to Gulgaky's hard work, today her business contains one dairy cow, one heifer and one calf.  She also works on 0.60 hectares of land, where she annually plants clover.  The monthly income amounts to 15,000 som (KGS).  In order to further develop her business, Gulgaky requested a loan in the amount of 70,000 som (KGS) from the microfinance bank "Bai-Tushum and Partners" to buy cows in order to increase livestock headcount.  Gulgaky plans to invest the earnings from the loan into further increasing domestic livestock quantities and plans to save money for her children's continued education.

loans.use: to buy cows in order to increase livestock headcount

loans.name: Sinat's Group

texts.en:
Sinat, 38, is married and lives with her family in a village of the Tbaung Khmum district. She has three children, two of whom are in school. 

To make a living, she has been farming rice and raising pigs for almost 20 years; the current business earns her family about 30,000 KHR per day.

Sinat has been with VisionFund for one cycle. Sinat is now leading her group to ask for a loan. 

As the leader, Sinat is going to use her portion to build a piggery and buy more piglets to raising. She hopes to fatten her pigs to make a better living.

loans.use: To build a piggery and buy more piglets to raise

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Tbaung Khmum district

loans.name: Anvarjon

texts.ru: Анварджон родился в 1995 году. Он окончил среднюю школу успешно в этом году и поступил в Таджикский Государственный Университет Коммерции. Он поступил по специальности товаровед. Анварджон не женат и живет с родителями. Он должен оплатить за учебный договор, но не имеет денег. Он запрашивает займ на сумму 700 долларов США для оплаты учебного договора. Он ждет вашу доброту и надеется на ваше милосердие.
texts.en: Anvarjon was born in 1995.  He successfully completed secondary school this year and was accepted to the Tajikistan State University of Commerce.  He will be majoring in merchandising.  Anvarjon is not married and lives with his parents.  He has to pay for his tuition contract, but does not have money.  He is requesting a loan in the amount of 700 US dollars to pay for his tuition.  He awaits your kindness and hopes for your mercy.

loans.use: to pay for university tuition

loans.name: Benilda

texts.en:
This is Benilda. Her previous loan was a big help to her business. She was able to buy the needed spare parts and accessories for her tricycles. Her income from her business helped in her family's everyday expenses. She now has two tricycle units. 

She would like to apply for another 19,000 PHP loan to buy spare parts and for the maintenance of her tricycle unit. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Benilda dreams to have another tricycle unit and hopes to become rich. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her life and business every week and draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for spare parts and maintenance of her tricycles.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 40 years old and married with 3 children. She owns a green grocery shop in Nairobi town which she has been running for one year. 

She gets an income of 8,500 Kenya Shillings each month and will use the loan to open another grocery shop. She will also use part of it to buy more stock of vegetables and fruits for sale. This is her 1st loan term with KADET LTD and she will use her anticipated profits to pay for her children’s school fees. 

Jane's future hopes and dreams are to have a successful business and have a happy family.

loans.use: to open another grocery shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more stock of medicine.

loans.name: Isabella

texts.en:
Isabella is a hardworking lady. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and rent.

For the past three years, she has operated a business of selling leso (women wrap) cloth. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of expanding to become a big supplier of clothes in the future.

With the Kshs 30,000, she wants to purchase 40 pieces of lesos to sell. 

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase 40 pieces of lesos to sell.

loans.name: Chanthorn's Group

texts.en:
Chanthorn is aged 46 and married. She has two children. Her family lives in a village of the Ponhea Krek district of Kampong Cham province.  She and her husband earn a living through farming rice and planting cassava. Her husband helps to earn more income by working for others for a fee. The current business earns her about 20,000KHR per day to meet the family’s need. 
Chanthorn has been with VisionFund for two cycles and completely paid back the past loans which have helped her family relieve their financial burden to a great extent. She is now leading a group of two members to apply for another loan with VisionFund. As the leader, she is going to use her portion to buy fertilizers for her farmland. With this loan, she hopes to make more crops and sell it for a good price to make a better living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for her farmland

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Sam's Group

texts.en:
Sam, 44, is from a rural village located in the Cheuny Prey district of Kampong Cham province. She is married and has six children. She and her husband earn a living through farming rice. Engaging in this business for 22 years, she is able to earn about 27,000KHR per day. 
Sam has just started with VisionFund for this cycle. Now she is leading her group to ask for a loan. As the leader, she is going to use her portion to buy fertilizers for her farmland. With this loan, she hopes to increase her family’s income so as to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for her farmland

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Cheung Prey district

loans.name: Ren's Group

texts.en:
Ren is a 40-year-old married woman. She lives with her husband and their four children in a rural area located in the Cheung Prey district of Cambodia.

To earn a living, she works as a rice farmer. She works on 1 hectare of farmland, and she explains that she has been in this business for 22 years. Her business activities allow her to earn approximately 22,000 KHR per day to feed her family but she manages to save approximately 10,000 KHR per day.

This is the first loan Ren is seeking through Kiva’s partner, VisionFund. Now leading her two-person group in requesting a loan in the amount of 1,000,000 KHR each (2,000,000 KHR total), Ren would like to use the requested loan proceeds to purchase fertilizers and seeds for her farmland. She hopes this loan will enable her to expand her family’s business and to generate more income so that she can help to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To expand and improve her farming business by purchasing fertilizers and seeds

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Cheung Prey district

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites is a 40-year-old widow. She is blessed with three children. Currently, one of her children goes to school, one child works, and her youngest is still just an infant.

To earn a living, Marites manages a general store and restaurant within her local community. Marites has been engaged in this business for 22 years.

She is hoping to attract a smoother and more continuous flow of customers to her general store and restaurant. For her plan to be realistic, she is hoping to secure additional capital in the amount of 40,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase grocery items such as soft drinks, assorted biscuits and raw meat for her general store. She believes that the requested loan proceeds would help her general store and restaurant to be profitable in the future. She thanks lenders for their support.

loans.use: to expand and improve her general store business by purchasing additional grocery items (e.g., soft drinks, assorted biscuits, and raw meat)

loans.name: Revelita

texts.en:
Revelita is 65 years of age, married and blessed with eight children. She is grateful because her hard work and determination has helped her in the realization of her dream to her eight children. Revelita offers construction supplies, electric appliances and kitchen utensils for seven years. At her age, she sell the products through made to order.

Revelita aspires for continuous growth of her business, so she's requesting for a loan of PHP 45,000. This amount will be use to buy a washing machine, refrigerator, galvanized iron and electric wire for her vending activity. Revelita is hoping that she could obtain her requested loan in order to improve her financial stability and way of life.

loans.use: to buy a washing machine, refrigerator, galvanized iron and electric wire for her vending activity

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William is 35 years old.  He is married and is blessed with three children between ten and six years old.  His main source of income comes from an animal sales business in Nandi county and its neighboring counties. He has been in this business for a period of over seven years.  He gets an average  monthly profit of Kshs 12,000.

He is borrowing a fourth loan of Kshs 80,000 from KADET LTD. and intends to use this amount to purchase animals for resale. The profits he earns will be used to to increase his working capital and expand the current business.  His dream is to be financially stable.

loans.use: To purchase animals for sale

loans.name: Koeun's Group

texts.en:
Koeun is a 49-year- old widow. She is blessed with one child.

To earn a living, she grows rice and works for others for fees. She typically earns approximately 28,000 KHR per day to cover her costs of living.

Koeun is new to VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). She is now leading her first micro-loan group, which consists of five members total. She and her co-borrowers are seeking 1,000,000 KHR each (5,000,000 KHR). As the leader, she would like to use her loan portion on labor costs and plowing fees and to purchase fertilizers for her crops. She hopes that the loan proceeds will enable her to boost her yield and triple her income.

loans.use: To expand and improve her farming operations by purchasing fertilizers for her crops

loans.name: Thik's Group

texts.en: Thik is 24 years old, married, and a young mother of one daughter who is too young for school. She is a resident of the Battambang province’s Moung Russey district. She grows rice as her primary source of income to cover the daily cost of living while her husband has helped her in doing farming. This is the seventh cycle loan for Thik and she has completely repaid the past loans. The past loans have help her better support her family's living condition. Now Thik’s group is composed of four female members to request another loan with VisionFund. As the leader, she will spend her loan portion to buy fertilizer for her cultivated land. She hopes to increase cash-crop yield so as to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her cultivated land

loans.name: Annetta

texts.en:
Annetta is 35 years old and married with four children ages 1, 4, 8, and 18. Three of the children attend school, and the family lives in Montserrado County, which is the number-one commercial city and capital of Liberia. 

Annetta is a high school graduate. Since 2007 she has been involved with a cook shop business, selling rice and soup. Most interestingly, she has many customers since she sells delicious Liberian food. She started her business with a loan from her husband and learned this way of selling from her friends. She spends eight hours on her business each day. Because the location of her shop is a bit far from her house, one of the problems she faces is vehicle traffic, which sometimes causes her to be late to open her cook shop. 

Annetta is requesting a loan to buy food ingredients, such as pepper, fish, meat, vita (a juice drink) and oil, to expand her business. She plans to expand her business even more and educate her children.

loans.use: to buy food ingredients, such as pepper, fish, meat, vita and oil, to expand her business

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is married woman with one child who is still underage. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and rental bills. 

For the past three years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenges. Janet dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 50,000 she wants to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, and cooking oil

loans.name: Samaleswari Group

texts.en:
Farzana, an active Muslim married lady of 27, is a permanent resident of Khariar town of Nuapada in Odisha, India. The energetic lady standing on the extreme right with raised hand in the photograph is Farzana. She resides with her husband and one son of three years old. To increase the income of her family, in the year 2013, Farzana, along with  four other older women clients of Mahashakti Foundation formed a group named Samaleswari to access loans from Mahashakti Foundation. This is the first loan for her and fourth loan for the other members.

Farzana herself has been running a fancy store in the daily market of Khariar town for last fifteen years with the help of her husband. She basically sells ladies' items like bangles, talc, combs, oil; face cream, plastic items, cosmetics, ornaments, etc. Farzana brings the stock for her fancy store from the wholesale market 200 kms away, that is from Raipur. Presently she is selling fancy items amounting to 1500 INR to 2000 INR per day from which she gets 15 to 20 %. profit. From this small income she is hardly able to cover her family expenses. So she wants to increase the volume of her business to increase the income.

 From this loan amount, Farzana purchases fancy items like bangles, talc, combs, oil; face cream, plastic items, cosmetics, ornaments, etc. in bulk to save the transport cost  and loss due to rate fluctuation. Farzana assumes that this investment will be profitable for her. She hopes to provide better education to her son and develop her business into a wholesale store in future.

The other four members of the group are Parwati, Nrupamani, Santoshi and Sushama who are running vegetable vending businesses in the daily market.

loans.use: To pay for purchasing bangles, talc, combs, oil; face cream, plastic items, cosmetics, ornaments, etc

loans.name: Sokkong

texts.en: Sokkong is a young mother of two little kids residing in the Thmor Koul district of Battambang province. To earn a living, she does rice farming on a one-hectare area and raises two pigs, whereas working for others for a fee provides supplementary income from her husband. Sokkong is a first-time borrower with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). She will spend the loan amount she is requesting to buy eight pigs for raising and to build a decent pigpen. She will spend a portion of it on purchasing fertilizer for her rice paddy. She hopes to gain a good income to support her children.

loans.use: To buy eight pigs for raising and to build a decent pigpen

loans.name: Vicent

texts.en: Vicent used the previous loan to buy seedlings to plant. He is a hardworking man living in Fort Portal, Uganda with a personal goal of building a permanent house for residence. He has been operating a retail shop for the last seven years and faces a hardship of inadequate capital to purchase stock. However, he has a vision of diversifying his business to include farming and own a wholesale shop. Vicent intends to use the loan to buy seedlings for planting.

loans.use: to buy seedlings for planting.

loans.name: Maa Durga Group

texts.en:
Jaenti, aged 39, is a hard-working lady from Chhata village of Nuapada district in Odisha, India. Chhata is a remotely located rural village. The lady standing second from right with raised hand is Jaenti. She is residing with her husband, two sons of 14 and 11 and one daughter of 16 years who are locally continuing their studies. 

Jaenti herself has been running a general store in her village with daily-need items like potatoes, rice, oil, soap, shampoo, biscuits, tea, sugar, etc. for the last 10 years. Her husband helps in her business like bringing stock from the nearest town for her general store. She earns a monthly income of 5000 INR from the existing business which is just hand to mouth for the family. 

In the year 2010 Jaenti, along with other four members of her village, formed a Joint Liability Group to access loans from Mahashakti Foundation for developing their business. Prior to this loan  Jaenti already accessed two loans from Mahashakti Foundation and each time she was able to add some extra items to her shop. This is the third loan for her  and from  this loan she wants to  purchase stock of potatoes, rice, oil, soap, shampoo, biscuits, tea, sugar, etc. in bulk  from the nearest wholesale market to avoid the regular transportation cost and loss due to price variation. She also wants to purchase a refrigerator for starting cold drinks selling. 

Jaenti believes she can earn more income from this investment which will help her to manage her family finances smoothly. She hopes to construct a good house and arrange the marriage ceremony of her daughter in a decent manner.

The other four members of the groups are Puspanjali, Lalmati, Bhuleswari and Shrimati with rice haller, general store, milk selling and paddy procurement businesses respectively.

loans.use: To pay for  purchasing potatoes, rice, oil, soap, shampoo, biscuits, tea, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Sarom

texts.en: Originally from Battambang province, Sarom is 44 years old and married. She has nine children, but currently only three kids still count on her as they are in school. For her entire household, three hectares of rice farming provide the sole income to cover the family's daily food and other necessary expenses. Sarom has been involved in the current business for 15 years. This is not her first loan with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). The past loans, which she has fully repaid, have enabled her to improve her living conditions. Now she is taking out a new loan to buy herbicide for her crop. She hopes to gain a good yield from her paddy farm and triple her income.

loans.use: To buy herbicide for her crop

loans.name: Sopheap's Group

texts.en: Sopheap is a resident of the Sangke district of Battambang province. She has been blessed with two little kids to cater for. She makes a living via a fruit-selling business; it is the business that she has had for 10 years. This is the fifth time that Sopheap and her co-borrower have borrowed with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). She has succeeded in repaying her past loan wisely to upgrade her living condition, especially she is able to afford to provide daily sufficient food for her children. Now she and her joint borrower are seeking 1,400,000 KHR each. As the leader, she will spend her loan portion to buy more fruit for resale. She hopes to replenish her fruit-selling business on time and make more income for her family.

loans.use: To buy more fruit for resale

loans.name: Sara Group

texts.en: This group is called Sara and is comprised of four ladies. They applied for a loan of 140,000 Yemeni Rial (YER). Hadia lives in Hodeida, Yemen. She is 35 years old. She has been selling clothes for ladies. She is a professional in this field and her goods are required in the market. She started her business with little capital. She is applying for a loan of 50,000 YER to buy clothes to expand her business. Her extra income from the loan will be added to her savings to expand her business and improve the living standards of the family. Her dream is to expand her business in order to sell different products.

loans.use: to buy clothes to expand her business.

loans.name: Soeurth's Group

texts.en: Soeurth is a mother of three schoolchildren residing in Thmor Koul district of Battambang province. Her main source of income is from soybean farming and rice farming. It is the business that she has had for 10 years. This is not the first loan for Soeurth with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). After the successful loan which she has fully repaid back, she feels confident that she can improve her living condition better than before. For this new cycle, she forms a group of two to get a new loan with VisionFund. She is asking for 1,400,000 KHR while her co-borrower is applying for 500,000 KHR. As the leader, she will use her loan portion to buy fertilizer for her farmland and pay for transplantation fee. She hopes to gain a good yield from her cash-crop so that she can make a good income to support her living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her farmland

loans.name: Jorge Antonio

texts.es:
Jorge es un joven de 26 años, se le conoce como una persona trabajadora y muy responsable en sus obligaciones personales y familiares, el vive con su compañera de vida y su hija, la cual tiene a apenas 2 años de nacida.

Desde hace 17 años desarrolla labores agrícolas, actividad que se hace a la fecha muy fácil realizar, además cuenta con el apoyo de su compañera de vida, la cual trabaja con el ganado y ella tiene más de 7 años de realizar la actividad del ordeño, ambos son muy trabajadores..

El crédito lo solicita, para la compra de insumos agrícolas, como abono y pesticida para el cultivo, ya que el tiene 21,000 metros cuadrados de maíz sembrado.
El beneficio del crédito será que podrá mantener en perfecto estado la milpa, la cual traerá muchos ingresos económicos a la familia, además de poder dejar una reserva para consumo familiar de la misma cosecha. 
  
Desea a futuro construir una vivienda en un terreno, que el padre está por heredarle, además sueña con ver a su hija terminar sus estudios y que sea una persona de bien, y terminar su vida al lado de su compañera de vida y sus nietos.
texts.en:
Jorge is 26 years old. He says he is known for being hard-working and for being responsible with his personal and family obligations. He lives with his life partner and their daughter, who is just two years old.

Jorge has worked in agriculture for 17 years, which he says now makes the work very easy to do. Moreover, he now has the help of his partner, who works with the cattle. She has been doing the milking for seven years now. He says they are both very hard-working. 

Jorge is requesting this loan to buy agricultural supplies such as fertilizer and pesticide for his crops. He says he has 21,000 square meters of corn planted. Jorge says this loan will help him maintain his crop in perfect condition. This way his family can make a good profit and keep a portion of the harvest for themselves.

Jorge says that, in the future, he would like to build a home on a plot of land that he is about to inherit from his father. He also dreams of seeing his daughter finish school and grow up to be a good person. He hopes to spend his later years with his partner and their grandchildren.

loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies such as fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.name: Maa Mangala Group

texts.en:
Maa Mangala is a Joint Liability Group formed by five women of Luthurbandh village of Balangir district in Odisha, India in the year 2010. Luthurbandh is a rural village located twenty kms from the nearest town, Titilagarh. The objective of forming the group was to access a loan from Mahashakti Foundation and expand the businesses. 

Rupeswari, a headstrong and confident lady, is one of these five women. She hails from a poor family living below the poverty line. The lady sitting in the middle in the photo raising her hand is Rupeswari, She is forty-eight years old and lives with her husband, one daughter of 22 years and one son of 25 years who help her in all activities. 

Rupeswari has been running a small dry food vending business for the last eight years. Her husband travels to the six nearest villages for selling of dry food items like bread, rolls, and biscuits, etc. every day. Rupeswari earns a monthly income of 4,000 INR from the above business. With this income, she is hardly able to manage her household expenses. So, she wants to expand her business by taking out a loan from Mahashakti Foundation. With the present loan, Rupeswari wants to purchase more stock of bread, rolls biscuits, etc. This will help her to meet the demand of the customers. 

Rupeswari hopes to save enough to construct a house of her own and do wholesaling of  dry food items. The other four members of the group are Rita, Pramila, Bati and Bisakha who are running   businesses like a tailoring centre, a general store, and milk selling and cloth vending respectively.

loans.use: To pay for purchasing bread, rolls, biscuits, etc.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 39 years old and married with three children, aged 16, 7 and 5 years old. She runs a cereals shop in Oloitoktok town. She has been in this business for 11 years, and her current monthly income is 29,300 Kenya shillings. 

This is her third loan term with KADET LTD, and she intends to buy more stock of beans, maize and rice to sell. This will enable her have enough stock and thereby meet the demands of her customers. She will use the generated income to expand her business and become a cereal wholesaler. 

Jane's hope for the future is to provide a better education for her children.

loans.use: To buy more stock of cereals to sell.

loans.name: Ergashaly

texts.en:
Ergashaly is an entrepreneur who is married and has 5 children. He has been busy with animal husbandry for more than 20 years; he has great experience in this field. Thanks to the animals' good condition, he has managed to win a large quantity of customers for his business. He sells his animals in the local market; many of his customers are local butchers who are glad for his work. 

Ergashaly is looking for a loan to buy young cattle. In this way he will be able to offer his customers good animals and continue to make financial progress, providing his household with good earnings. He is asking for a loan of 2100 USD to buy young cattle for developing business further. He awaits your support.

loans.use: to buy young cattle for developing business

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
Juanita is 47 years old and married with two children. She earns a living by farming vegetables in the Philippines. Juanita is borrowing PHP 28,000 through NWTF in order to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Juanita has been farming vegetables for seven years and also earns additional income from her general store.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is the mother of two children; one in in school and the other is still young. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water.

She has operated a retail shop business for the past three years, selling household consumables like wheat flour, maize flour, and sugar. 

With the loan she is requesting she wants to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour, soap, tea leaves, and wheat flour for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour, soap, tea leaves, and wheat flour for resale

loans.name: Fred

texts.en: Fred is 39 year old married man with children living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He operates a transport business, specifically motorcycle, and also does farming to earn extra income. His major challenge is poor roads that become almost impassable during the rainy season. His dream is to own at least five motorcycles which he will hire out and receive 80% of the daily earnings from each motorcycle per day. Fred intends to use the loan to buy a motorcycle for his transport business.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle for his transport business.

loans.name: Jaya Radhika Group

texts.en:
Jaya Radhika  group was formed in the year 2013 by six women members of Below Poverty Line category from the village Mahulpada in the district of Bolangir in Odisha; India to access loans from Mahashakti Foundation. Mahulpada is a small rural village located at eighty kms from the district headquarters of Balangir.  Dushila is one of the members of this group. She is standing third from the right with raised hand in the photo. She is 48 years old; living with her husband, son, daughter in-law and a granddaughter of 2 years. 

Dushila has a small milk selling business, having a milk cow which she purchased from the first loan from Mahashakti Foundation. She gets 5 liters of milk per day, which she supplies in the nearby town. Apart from this, she is working as a 4th grade employee in the Integrated Child Development Dept. of Govt. of Odisha. From the above two sources, Dushila gets a monthly income of 6000 INR. According to her, the present income is insufficient on her part to manage her household expenses.  So, as there is growing demand for milk in the locality, she has planned to utilize the present loan for purchasing another cow of improved variety to add some extra income to her family. Dushila says this will help her to add some extra income and she will be able to manage her family finances smoothly. Dushila has also a dream to develop a dairy farm in future.

The other five members of this group are Nilendri & Nabami with milk business, Dahane with goat trading, Jamuna with general store and Sukanti with vegetable cultivation and vending business.

loans.use: To pay for purchasing a cow

loans.name: Allaha Group

texts.en:
This group named Allaha was formed in the year 2013 by four women of Titilagarh town with an objective of accessing loans from Mahashakti Foundation for developing their existing businesses. Among the four members, two are old members who have already taken a first loan from Mahashakti Foundation. Buji is one of them.

 The lady sitting on the extreme right with raised hand in the photo is Buji. She is thirty-eight years old; living with her husband, two sons aged 16, 12 and two daughters aged 18 & 14. Buji has been running a vegetable shop in her house for the last five years. She sells vegetables like tomatoes, potatoes, onions, 'brinjal', ladies' fingers, chilis, etc. She brings stock from the local wholesalers. She earns a monthly income of 5000 INR which makes it very hard on her part to manage her six-member family's finances. Earning more income is the only way out for her. So to expand her business, Buji has planned to purchase more stock of tomatoes, potatoes, onions, 'brinjal', ladies' fingers, chili, etc. from the present loan amount. She hopes to save money for the marriages of her grown-up daughters.

The other three members of her group are Sapna, Madina and Subha  doing fancy store, wheat flour sales,  and vegetable vending businesses.

loans.use: To pay for purchasing tomatoes, potatoes, onions, 'brinjal', ladies' fingers, chili, etc.

loans.name: Kumba

texts.en: Kumba is a 49-year-old woman, married, with three children ages 3, 14, and 18, who are in school; they live in Montserrado county. Kumba did not attend school. For the past six years she has been running a shop where she sells many items such as soft drinks, rice, and oil.
